name: Token represents direct ownership of underlying asset
description: Issuer claims the token is a title to the underlying — holding the token means owning the asset (gold bar, real estate parcel, etc).
realWorldExamples: Paxos Gold: each PAXG = one troy ounce of gold
TER Gold: gold-backed SPL token

name: Token represents a share in a fund or SPV
description: Issuer claims the token represents a share/unit in a fund, trust, or SPV that holds the underlying assets. Holder owns the token, fund owns the asset.
realWorldExamples: BlackRock BUIDL: share in USD Institutional Digital Liquidity Fund
Ondo OUSG: share in Ondo I LP holding SHV ETF
Apollo ACRED: share in Diversified Credit Fund

name: Token represents registered equity (stock) in a company
description: Token represents actual shares in a company, recorded on the company's share register.
realWorldExamples: Exodus EXOD: Class A common stock
Opening Bell by Superstate: on-chain equity issuance

name: Token represents a tracker certificate / synthetic exposure
description: Token tracks the price of an underlying but holder does not directly own the underlying. Holder has a claim against the issuer, not against the asset.
realWorldExamples: Kraken xStocks: tracker certificates by Backed Assets
Ondo Global Markets: exposure tokens backed 1:1 by broker-dealer

name: Token holder has same claim priority as direct instrument holder
description: Legal counsel confirms that the token holder's legal claim priority is identical to what they'd have if they held the underlying instrument directly (e.g., same as a direct fund shareholder).
realWorldExamples: SVB exposed this was NOT true for USDC — holder was unsecured creditor of Circle, not direct claimant on reserves

name: Token transfer conveys all underlying rights without additional steps
description: Transferring the token automatically transfers all associated rights. No separate filings (UCC), notices to borrowers, or consent of counterparties required.
realWorldExamples: Private credit: often FALSE — token transfers freely but underlying claim requires notice/consent
Bearer assets like USDY: TRUE by design

name: Token holder can enforce rights in specified jurisdiction
description: Legal opinion confirming the token holder's rights are enforceable in the specified jurisdiction's courts.
realWorldExamples: Kraken xStocks: enforceable under EU-approved prospectus
Cross-border products need per-jurisdiction opinions

name: Token holder can redeem token for underlying asset
description: Token holder has a contractual right to exchange the token back for the underlying asset or its cash equivalent, under defined terms.
realWorldExamples: Paxos Gold: redeemable for physical gold
Ondo USDY: redeemable for USD
BlackRock BUIDL: redeemable for USD via Securitize

name: Underlying assets held in custody by named custodian
description: The specific custodian holding the underlying assets is identified and confirmed.
realWorldExamples: BlackRock BUIDL at Komainu
Ondo USDY at Coinbase Custody
Paxos Gold at Brink's vaults

name: Custodian independently confirms it holds the assets
description: The custodian itself (not just the issuer) confirms it is holding the assets. A stronger claim than the issuer saying 'custodied at X'.
realWorldExamples: Brink's vault audit for Oro GOLD
Rare today — most custody claims come from the issuer, not the custodian directly

name: Customer assets segregated from custodian proprietary assets
description: The custodian holds customer assets in segregated accounts, separate from its own assets. Critical for insolvency protection.
realWorldExamples: SVB: Circle didn't disclose segregation mechanics at each banking partner

name: Custodian is regulated under specified regime
description: The custodian is licensed/regulated by a named financial authority (OCC, NYDFS, FCA, MAS, etc).
realWorldExamples: Coinbase Custody: NYDFS-regulated
Anchorage Digital: OCC-chartered
Komainu: regulated in Jersey/Dubai

name: Customer assets are not rehypothecated
description: Custodian or issuer confirms that customer assets are not lent out, pledged, or used for any purpose other than custody.
realWorldExamples: Important for gold products
Relevant for T-bill funds: are the T-bills used in repo?

name: Reserve value >= outstanding token supply
description: The total value of reserve assets equals or exceeds the total value of all outstanding tokens. The core proof-of-reserves claim.
realWorldExamples: Ondo USDY: reserve proof at ondo.finance/usdy/reserves
Remora Markets: monthly proof-of-reserve audits

name: Reserve balance independently verified by third party
description: A third-party auditor or attestor (not the issuer) has independently verified the reserve balance. Stronger than issuer self-reporting.
realWorldExamples: Ondo USDY: Ankura audit report
Oro GOLD: third-party monthly attestations

name: Reserve composition disclosed (asset types and percentages)
description: The issuer discloses what the reserves actually consist of — T-bills, bank deposits, repos, etc. — and their relative proportions.
realWorldExamples: BlackRock BUIDL: cash, T-bills, repos
USDC: SVB exposed that reserve composition (bank deposits) was the risk

name: Reserve concentration risk disclosed (top custodian/counterparty exposure)
description: Issuer discloses concentration: what % of reserves sit with the top 1-3 custodians or counterparties, and what happens if one fails.
realWorldExamples: SVB: Circle had $3.3B (8% of reserves) at one bank — concentration not salient in disclosures

name: Proof-of-reserves report is publicly published
description: Issuer publishes an explicit proof-of-reserves report (or dedicated reserve page) that can be independently reviewed by token holders.
realWorldExamples: Ondo USDY: reserve proof page
Remora Markets: monthly proof-of-reserve audits

name: Physical asset verified to exist at claimed storage location
description: A verifier has physically confirmed the asset (gold, uranium, etc.) exists at the stated location.
realWorldExamples: Oro GOLD: vault audit by Brink's
Uranium Digital: yellowcake at conversion facilities

name: Physical asset meets specified quality/purity standard
description: The physical asset meets an industry-recognized quality standard (LBMA Good Delivery, ASTM grade, etc).
realWorldExamples: Paxos Gold: LBMA Good Delivery standard
Oro GOLD: purity check posted on-chain on Solana

name: Physical asset quantity matches outstanding token supply
description: The number of physical units (ounces of gold, pounds of uranium) equals the outstanding token supply.
realWorldExamples: Paxos Gold: allocated gold bars matching PAXG supply
Tether Gold: gold matching XAUT supply

name: Blockchain is the authoritative ownership record
description: The on-chain token ledger is the legal system of record for ownership. If chain and off-chain records disagree, chain wins.
realWorldExamples: Paxos Gold: blockchainIsMainLedger=yes
Ondo USDY: blockchainIsMainLedger=yes
TER Gold: blockchainIsMainLedger=yes

name: Off-chain register is the authoritative ownership record
description: A traditional share register or transfer agent record is the legal system of record. Chain is a mirror/convenience layer. If they disagree, off-chain wins.
realWorldExamples: BlackRock BUIDL: Securitize transfer agent is legal record
Most tokenized MMFs and equities

name: On-chain balances reconciled with off-chain register as of [date]
description: Attestation that a reconciliation was performed and the on-chain token balances matched the off-chain share register at the stated date/time.
realWorldExamples: Products where off-chain register is primary: reconciliation confirms chain mirrors register

name: Zero unresolved reconciliation breaks as of [date]
description: There are currently no discrepancies between on-chain and off-chain records. All previously identified breaks have been resolved.
realWorldExamples: SVB: reconciliation breaks were invisible because reporting cadence was monthly

name: Reconciliation performed at stated cadence (daily/weekly/monthly)
description: The issuer commits to and performs reconciliation at a specific frequency.
realWorldExamples: Zach: crisis-cadence (hourly) needed under stress, not just monthly

name: Transfer agent is SEC-registered (or equivalent)
description: The entity maintaining the official share register is registered as a transfer agent with the SEC or equivalent regulator.
realWorldExamples: Securitize: SEC-registered transfer agent for BUIDL
Superstate: SEC-registered transfer agent for Opening Bell

name: Assets are bankruptcy-remote from issuer
description: If the issuer goes bankrupt, the underlying assets are held in a structure (SPV, trust) that protects them from the issuer's creditors.
realWorldExamples: Key question for all fund-structure tokens
SVB: was USDC bankruptcy-remote from Circle? Unclear for 48 hours

name: Token holder claim priority is defined in issuer insolvency
description: Legal opinion specifies what claim priority (secured, unsecured, pari passu, etc.) a token holder would have if the issuer became insolvent.
realWorldExamples: SVB: no USDC holder knew if they were a secured or unsecured creditor of Circle

name: Token holder claim priority defined in custodian insolvency
description: Legal opinion specifies what happens to the assets if the custodian (not the issuer) becomes insolvent.
realWorldExamples: SVB: the core question was custodian (bank) insolvency, not issuer insolvency

name: Settlement is final after N block confirmations
description: The product defines a specific number of block confirmations after which a transaction is considered irreversibly settled.
realWorldExamples: Ethereum-based tokens: commonly 12-64 confirmations
Solana: single slot finality

name: Issuer has authority to reverse/freeze transactions
description: The issuer (or an admin key) can freeze addresses, reverse transfers, or claw back tokens. This is a factual claim, not a value judgment — risk committees need to know.
realWorldExamples: Most regulated tokens have freeze/blacklist functions
Paxos Gold: contract has freeze capability
TER Gold: forcedTransfers=yes

name: Issuer has no ability to reverse/freeze transactions
description: The smart contract has no admin functions for freezing, blacklisting, or clawing back tokens. Once transferred, only the holder can move the tokens.
realWorldExamples: True bearer instruments — rare in regulated RWA tokens

name: Transaction reversal authority held by named role/entity
description: If reversals are possible, the specific entity or role (court oracle, compliance officer, multisig) that can authorize them is identified.
realWorldExamples: Attestify model: court oracle only
Most current products: issuer admin key

name: Settlement timing gap between token and underlying is documented
description: The time difference between when the token settles (seconds) and when the underlying settles (T+1, T+2, weekends) is explicitly documented.
realWorldExamples: Tokenized T-bill margin call at 2am Saturday: token settles instantly, Treasury settles Monday
Theo thBILL: underlying collateral settled within 4 business days

name: Loss allocation is defined for settlement finality breach
description: If settlement finality breaks (reorg, depeg, rail failure), there is a pre-agreed rule for who bears the loss: issuer, holder, insurer, or reserve fund.
realWorldExamples: SVB: USDC holders bore the depeg loss (temporarily). Loss allocation was undefined.

name: Admin operations require N-of-M multisig
description: All admin operations (freeze, mint, burn, upgrade) require approval from N out of M identified signers. Single-signer admin keys are explicitly flagged.
realWorldExamples: Zach: single-signer admin keys are disqualifying. Minimum 3-of-5.
Verifiable on-chain from multisig contract config

name: Parameter changes subject to timelock (Nh/Nd)
description: Changes to token parameters (fees, limits, oracles) are subject to a mandatory delay, allowing holders to react before changes take effect.
realWorldExamples: Zach: 48h minimum for parameters, 7d for logic upgrades, 30d for migrations

name: Contract logic upgrades subject to timelock (Nd)
description: Upgrades to the core smart contract logic require a mandatory delay (e.g., 7 days) before taking effect.
realWorldExamples: Verifiable on-chain from timelock contract config

name: All admin operations are logged on-chain
description: Every admin action (key rotation, parameter change, freeze, mint) emits an on-chain event, creating an auditable trail.
realWorldExamples: Standard for well-implemented ERC-20 admin functions
Zach: evidence of exercise, not just existence

name: Smart contract has no critical vulnerabilities (audited)
description: An independent security auditor has reviewed the smart contract and found no critical or high-severity vulnerabilities.
realWorldExamples: BlackRock BUIDL: audited by Securitize/third party
Standard practice for ERC-20 tokens

name: Smart contract correctly implements specified token standard
description: Auditor confirms the contract correctly implements ERC-20, SPL, ASA, or other relevant token standard.
realWorldExamples: ERC-20 compliance for Ethereum tokens
SPL token-2022 compliance for Solana tokens

name: NAV per token is $X as of [date]
description: The computed net asset value per token at a specific date/time, based on underlying asset valuations.
realWorldExamples: Franklin Templeton FOBXX: daily NAV on Stellar
BlackRock BUIDL: daily NAV via Securitize

name: Price/NAV feed provided by named oracle with max latency
description: An on-chain oracle provides the token's price or NAV, with a defined maximum update latency (e.g., every 24h or on 1% deviation).
realWorldExamples: Chainlink Proof of Reserve for PAXG
Pyth price feeds

name: Fund/issuer financial statements audited per GAAS/IFRS
description: The fund's or issuer's financial statements have been audited by a recognized auditor under GAAS, IFRS, or equivalent standards.
realWorldExamples: BlackRock BUIDL: fund financials audited
Franklin Templeton: SEC-registered fund with annual audits

name: Issuer licensed/registered with named financial regulator
description: The issuer holds a specific license or registration from a financial regulator.
realWorldExamples: Paxos: NYDFS-regulated
Franklin Templeton: SEC-registered investment company

name: Product registered/approved under named regulation
description: The specific token/product (not just the issuer) is registered or approved under a named regulation (Reg D, EU Prospectus, etc).
realWorldExamples: Exodus EXOD: SEC-registered
Kraken xStocks: EU-approved prospectus

name: All token holders have passed KYC verification
description: Every address holding the token has been verified through KYC procedures. Enforced via on-chain whitelist.
realWorldExamples: BlackRock BUIDL: via Securitize
Most regulated MMF tokens

name: Token transfers restricted to whitelisted addresses only
description: The smart contract enforces that tokens can only be transferred to pre-approved (whitelisted) addresses.
realWorldExamples: BlackRock BUIDL: transfer-restricted
Ondo OUSG: transfer-restricted to qualified purchasers

name: Token transfers are unrestricted (permissionless)
description: Any address can receive the token without pre-approval. True bearer instrument behavior.
realWorldExamples: Ondo USDY: unconditionalTransfers=yes
Paxos Gold: unconditionalTransfers=yes
Kraken xStocks: unconditionalTransfers=yes

name: Halt triggers are defined for blockchain-level exceptions
description: The product has pre-defined conditions (reorg depth, oracle staleness, bridge failure) that trigger a halt in issuance/redemption.
realWorldExamples: Multi-chain tokens (BUIDL via Wormhole): bridge compromise triggers
Solana outage protocols

name: Loss allocation pre-agreed for chain reorg/rollback events
description: If a chain reorg causes double-spend or lost finality, there is a pre-agreed rule for who bears the loss.
realWorldExamples: Relevant for public-chain tokens. Most products don't disclose this.

name: Failover procedure defined for asymmetric rail availability
description: If the token rail (blockchain) is available but the underlying rail (TradFi settlement) is not (or vice versa), there is a defined failover procedure.
realWorldExamples: T-bill collateral transfer Saturday night: token settles, T-bill doesn't until Monday

name: Stress scenarios and their impact on equivalence are disclosed
description: The issuer has documented specific stress scenarios (custodian failure, depeg, rail outage) and their impact on token holder rights and value.
realWorldExamples: SVB: stress scenario (single custodian failure) was not disclosed as a peg-breaking risk

name: Top 3 dependencies that can break equivalence are identified
description: Issuer identifies the 3 most critical dependencies (custodian, oracle, gateway) whose failure would break the token's equivalence to the underlying.
realWorldExamples: Zach's 5 questions: 'What are the top three dependencies that can break equivalence, and what are the triggers?'

name: Token transfer triggers legal assignment of underlying claim
description: When the token is transferred, the underlying credit claim is legally assigned to the new holder without additional steps.
realWorldExamples: Often FALSE — token transfers freely but underlying requires separate UCC filing or borrower notice

name: Token holder can directly enforce claim against borrower
description: The token holder (not just the issuer/servicer) has standing to enforce the underlying credit claim directly against the borrower.
realWorldExamples: Zach: 'can the tokenholder actually enforce the claim against the borrower, or just hold a token?'

name: Servicer obligations survive token transfer
description: The loan servicer's obligations (collection, reporting, workout) continue regardless of who holds the token.
realWorldExamples: Apollo ACRED: servicing by Apollo regardless of token holder

name: Payment waterfall computation is verifiable
description: Token holders can verify how payments from borrowers are allocated through the waterfall (senior/junior tranches, fees, etc).
realWorldExamples: Centrifuge: on-chain waterfall for some products
Most private credit: off-chain computation

name: Underlying tokenized product has been independently assessed
description: For wrapped/layered products: the underlying tokenized product's attestation posture has been reviewed by the wrapper issuer.
realWorldExamples: Theo thBILL: wraps tULTRA which wraps Libeara T-bill — each layer needs assessment

name: Conditions under which composed product degrades are identified
description: For wrapped/layered products: the issuer has identified specific conditions under which the wrapper's equivalence breaks due to an underlying layer failing.
realWorldExamples: Zach: 'We use BUIDL' is not sufficient. Need to say 'our equivalence degrades if...'
Felix USDhl: if underlying T-bill product breaks, USDhl breaks
